ygData.subject: Re: Automatically setting the Speciation Threshold

Bas, I like your solution to the problem and it sounds like it works 
well,=
 but I'd still be interested in what would happen if you do 
what Derek sug=
gests below.  In my experience, the most common 
culprit in needing a very =
high compatibility threshold is very fast 
addition of structure.  So it's =
at least worth checking whether 
going back to the classic rates changes th=
e situation positively. 

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <dj=
ames@g...> wrote:
>
> On 11/12/05, itsmebas <Bas@s...> wrote:
> >
> > BTW: =
I had set the coefficients for excess genes, disjoint genes 
and
> > weight=
 difference to 1, 1, and 2, respectively. Mutation rates 
are set
> > such =
that I get neural networks with a complexity of 100 to 200 
after
> > 500 g=
enerations (starting with 22 inputs, 3 outputs and one 
connection).
> 
> I=
 just wanted to point out, since Bas is using ANJI, that the 
mutation
> ra=
tes in ANJI work quite differently than they do in the original 
NEAT
> imp=
lementation.  There's a previous discussion of this in the 
archives
> I be=
lieve, so I won't go into it, but the basic result is that 
ANJI's
> mutati=
on rates add a lot more topology per generation than Ken's.
> 
> If you wan=
t to implement the mutation rates the way Ken did, just 
set
> the paramete=
r:
> 
> topology.mutation.classic
> 
> to TRUE.  This may have been part of=
 the difficulty in tuning
> speciation as well.  Don't know, but I thought =
I'd mention
> it...although now it sounds like you've got most of your issu=
es 
with
> speciation worked out.
> 
> Derek
>
